gmd:title.gco:CharacterString: Global Ocean Physics Forecast updated Daily

gmd:abstract.gco:CharacterString:
Short description:

The Operational Mercator global Ocean forecast system - at either 1/4 or 1/12 degree depending on areas- is running every day providing 7 days of 3D global ocean forecast. This product includes daily files of temperature, salinity, currents, sea level and ice parameters from the top to the bottom of the Ocean over various areas covering the Global Ocean.

Detailed description:

The Global Ocean is split up into 11 geographical areas with various resolutions and geographical projections (see below), in order to make file delivery easier.The files delivered are the following:

  • Global Ocean files: GLO - with 1/2 deg. horizontal resolution with regular lon/lat projection.
  • South Atlantic Ocean files: SAT - with 1/6 deg. horizontal resolution with Mercator projection.
  • North Pacific Ocean files: NPA - with 1/6 deg. horizontal resolution with Mercator projection.
  • Tropical Pacific Ocean files: TPA - with 1/4 deg. horizontal resolution with Mercator projection.
  • South Pacific Ocean files: SPA - with 1/6 deg. horizontal resolution with Mercator projection.
  • Indian Ocean files: IND - with 1/6 deg. horizontal resolution with Mercator projection.
  • Antarctic Ocean files: ACC - with 1/4 deg. horizontal resolution with Mercator projection.
  • Arctic Ocean files: ARC - with 1/8 deg. horizontal resolution with Stéréographic projection.
  • Mediteranean Sea files: MED - with 1/8 deg. horizontal resolution with Mercator projection.
  • North Atlantic Ocean files: NAT - with 1/6 deg. horizontal resolution with Mercator projection.
  • Tropical Atlantic Ocean files: TAT - with 1/4 deg. horizontal resolution wit Mercator projection.

Note that as an input for the TAT, NAT and MED areas, the Atlantic and Mediterranean Sea eddy resolving 1/12 degree system is used. For the GLO, SAT, NPA, SPA, TPA, IND, ACC and ARC areas, the 1/4 degree eddy permitting system is used.

Vertical coverage includes 43 levels ranging from 0 to 5500 meters (0 5 10 15 20 25 30 40 50 60 75 100 125 150 175 200 225 250 300 400 500 600 700 800 900 1000 1100 1200 1300 1400 1500 1750 2000 2250 2500 2750 3000 3250 3500 4000 4500 5000 5550 meters).

For the Mediterranean and Black Sea files, vertical coverage includes only 40 levels ranging from 0 to 4000 meters : 0 5 10 15 20 25 30 40 50 60 75 100 125 150 175 200 225 250 300 400 500 600 700 800 900 1000 1100 1200 1300 1400 1500 1750 2000 2250 2500 2750 3000 3250 3500 4000.

Outputs are delivered as daily mean files with Netcdf format (CF/COARDS 1.0 convention). Files are updated daily (before noon) including a new set of 7 days of forecasts.

Processing information:

The Mercator Ocean Global Ocean 1/4° and Atlantic and Mediterranean seat 1/12° forecasting system uses the NEMO (Nucleus for European Models of the Ocean) modeling system, coupled to the thermodynamic-dynamic sea ice model LIM2 EVP (Louvain sea Ice Model 2). The atmospheric forcing fields which drive the system are calculated from ECMWF operational atmospheric forecast using an empirical bulk formulae parameterization. The initial state of each forecast is provided by a weekly analysis every wednesday, described in the GLOBAL_ANALYSIS_FORECAST_PHYS_001_001_c products, and a daily update of this initial state thanks to an update of the ECMWF atmospheric analysis. The sea ice is fully comprehensive with the implementation of the LIM2 EVP model. With sea ice concentration, sea ice/snow thicknesses, sea ice drift and sea ice thermal content prognosed by this multi-layer model based on the Semtner 3-layers and the Hiblervisco-plastic formulations, the forecast handle most of the processes linked to the sea ice lifecycle.The combination of an energy-enstrophy conserving scheme for momentum advection with a partial steps representation of the bottom topography yields significant improvements in the mean circulation and in the representation of western boundary currents such as the Gulf Stream and the downstream flow of the North Atlantic Current. In order to better resolve the upper layers, the vertical grid has been refined at the surface ending with a discretization of 1m until 20m depth and of 500m for the bottom layers. This surface refined-mesh has been designed to improve the circulation in the coastal shelves and to represent more adequately the impact of the atmospheric diurnal cycle, which is explicitly modeled.

gmd:contactInstructions.gco:CharacterString: local service desk ; automatic notice accepted : yes

gmd:other.gco:CharacterString: sliding window of update as ISO8601, related to update processing time (positive after): -P7D/+P14D
